ai-an10:24.11.14_0: This venerable has no ill will ...
ai-an10:24.11.22_0: and corrupt wishes, so corrupt wishes don’t master them and keep going.’”
ai-an10:25.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these ten universal dimensions of meditation.
ai-an10:25.1.3_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, non-dual and limitless.
ai-an10:25.1.4_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal water ...
ai-an10:25.1.6_0: or the meditation on universal air.
ai-an10:25.1.8_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal yellow ...
ai-an10:25.1.9_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal red ...
ai-an10:25.1.10_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal white ...
ai-an10:25.1.11_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal space ...
ai-an10:25.1.12_0: They perceive the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, non-dual and limitless.
ai-an10:25.1.13_0: These are the ten universal dimensions of meditation.”
ai-an10:26.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kuraraghara on Steep Mountain.
ai-an10:26.1.2_0: Then Kāḷī of Kurughara went up to Mahākaccāna, and stood to one side.
ai-an10:26.1.3_0: “Sir, this was said by the Buddha in ‘The Maidens’ Questions’:
ai-an10:26.2.1_0: ‘I’ve reached the goal, peace of heart.
ai-an10:26.2.2_0: having conquered the army and dear,
ai-an10:26.2.4_0: that’s why I’m not a sneaker.
ai-an10:26.2.5_0: and no-one gets too close to me.’”
ai-an10:26.3.1_0: How should we see the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement?”
ai-an10:26.4.1_0: “Each of the earth, Sister, some ascetics and brahmins are reborn.
ai-an10:26.4.2_0: The Buddha directly knew the extent to which the attainment of the meditation on universal earth was the ultimate.
ai-an10:26.4.3_0: Directly knowing this he saw the beginning, the drawback, and the escape. And he saw the knowledge and vision of the variety of paths.
ai-an10:26.4.4_0: And they know the gratification, the drawback, and the escape of the path that ends.
ai-an10:26.5.2_0: Some ascetics and brahmins regard the attainment of the meditation on universal fire ...
ai-an10:26.5.9_0: universal consciousness to be the ultimate. Thinking ‘this is the goal’, they are reborn.
ai-an10:26.5.10_0: The Buddha directly knew the extent to which the attainment of the meditation on universal consciousness was the ultimate.
ai-an10:26.5.11_0: Directly knowing this he saw the beginning,
ai-an10:26.5.11_1: He went to the drawbacks of the drawback ...
ai-an10:26.5.12_0: And they know the gratification, the drawback, and the escape of the path that ends.
ai-an10:26.5.13_0: So, sister, that’s how to understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha said in brief in ‘The Maiden’s Questions’:
ai-an10:26.6.1_0: ‘I’ve reached the goal, peace of heart.
ai-an10:26.6.2_0: having conquered the army and dear,
ai-an10:26.6.4_0: that’s why I’m not a sneaker.
ai-an10:26.6.5_0: and no-one gets too close to me.’”
ai-an10:26.7.1_0: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”
ai-an10:27.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an10:27.1.4_0: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.
ai-an10:27.1.5_0: Why don’t we go to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths?”
ai-an10:27.2.1_0: Then they went to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-an10:27.2.1_1: and they exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.
ai-an10:27.2.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side,
ai-an10:27.2.2_1: Then those wanderers said to them:
ai-an10:27.3.1_0: “Reverends, the ascetic Gotama teaches his disciples like this:
ai-an10:27.3.2_0: ‘Please, mendicants, directly know all things. Meditate having directly known all things.’
ai-an10:27.3.3_0: We too teach our disciples in just the same way.
ai-an10:27.3.4_0: ‘Please, reverends, directly know all things. Live having directly known all things.’
ai-an10:27.3.5_0: What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s teaching and instruction and ours?”
ai-an10:27.4.1_0: Those mendicants neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-an10:27.4.2_0: got up from his seat and left:
ai-an10:27.4.3_0: “May we understand the meaning of this Buddha’s presence!”
ai-an10:27.5.1_0: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha.
ai-an10:27.5.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-an10:27.6.1_0: “Sir, we robed up in the morning and, taking our bowl and robe, and enter Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-an10:27.6.3_0: ‘It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.
ai-an10:27.6.4_0: Why don’t we go to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths?’
ai-an10:27.6.5_0: Then we went to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-an10:27.6.5_1: and they exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.
ai-an10:27.6.6_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side.
ai-an10:27.6.6_1: Then the wanderers said to them:
ai-an10:27.7.1_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama teaches his disciples like this:
ai-an10:27.7.2_0: Please, all of you, directly know all things. Meditate having directly known all things.
ai-an10:27.7.3_0: We too teach our disciples in just the same way.
ai-an10:27.7.4_0: Please, reverends, directly know all things. Live having directly known all things.
ai-an10:27.7.5_0: What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s teaching and instruction and ours?”
ai-an10:27.8.1_0: Then we neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-an10:27.8.2_0: I got up from my seat and left:
ai-an10:27.8.3_0: ‘I shall understand the meaning of the Buddha’s presence.’
ai-an10:27.9.1_0: “Mendicants, wanderers who follow other paths should say this to them:
ai-an10:27.9.2_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer. Two ... three ... four ... five ... six ... seven ... eight ... nine ... ten things: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’
ai-an10:27.9.3_0: Questioned like this, the wanderers who follow other paths would be stumped, and, in addition, would get frustrated.
ai-an10:27.9.6_0: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to these questions except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.
ai-an10:27.10.1_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’
ai-an10:27.10.2_0: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-an10:27.10.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.10.5_0: ‘All sentient beings are sustained by food.’
ai-an10:27.10.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding this one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.10.7_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’
ai-an10:27.10.8_0: That's why I said what I said.
ai-an10:27.11.1_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
ai-an10:27.11.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:27.11.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding two things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.11.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by two?
ai-an10:27.11.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these two things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.11.7_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said, and this is why he said it.
ai-an10:27.12.1_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
ai-an10:27.12.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:27.12.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding three things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.12.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by three?
ai-an10:27.12.5_0: There are three kinds of feelings:
ai-an10:27.12.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these three things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.12.7_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-an10:27.13.1_0: ‘The four questions: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
ai-an10:27.13.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:27.13.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding four things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.13.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by four?
ai-an10:27.13.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these four things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.13.7_0: That’s why I said the four questions: question, and this is why I said it.
ai-an10:27.14.1_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
ai-an10:27.14.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:27.14.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding five things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.14.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
ai-an10:27.14.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these five things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.14.7_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-an10:27.15.1_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
ai-an10:27.15.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:27.15.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding the six things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.15.4_0: What are the six fields of contact?
ai-an10:27.15.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these six things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.15.7_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said, and this is why he said it.
ai-an10:27.16.1_0: ‘Take seven things: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
ai-an10:27.16.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:27.16.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding seven things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.16.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by seven?
ai-an10:27.16.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these seven things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.16.7_0: ‘Take seven questions: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-an10:27.17.1_0: ‘Consciousness is a question, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
ai-an10:27.17.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:27.17.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding eight things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.17.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an10:27.17.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these eight things, seeing their cessation.
ai-an10:27.17.7_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-an10:27.18.1_0: ‘There’s Nine questions, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what I said,
ai-an10:27.18.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:27.18.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding nine things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.18.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by nine?
ai-an10:27.18.5_0: The nine abodes of sentient beings. ...
ai-an10:27.18.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these nine things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.18.7_0: ‘Dear ninety-six topics.’ That’s what I said, but this is why he said it.
ai-an10:27.19.1_0: ‘Ten things: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’
ai-an10:27.19.2_0: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-an10:27.19.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding ten things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.19.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:27.19.5_0: The ten ways of performing unskillful deeds.
ai-an10:27.19.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these ten things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:27.19.7_0: ‘Ten things: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’
ai-an10:27.19.8_0: That's what I said, and this is why he said it.”
ai-an10:28.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kajaṅgalā in a bamboo grove.
ai-an10:28.1.2_0: Then several lay followers went to the Kajaṅgalikā and approached her.
ai-an10:28.1.2_1: They bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-an10:28.1.2_2: The lay followers of Kajaṅgalikā said to her,
ai-an10:28.2.1_0: “Ma’am, this was said by the Buddha in ‘The Great Questions’:
ai-an10:28.2.2_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer. Two ... three ... four ... five ... six ... seven ... eight ... nine ... ten things: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’
ai-an10:28.2.3_0: How should we see the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement?”
ai-an10:28.3.1_0: “Good people, I haven’t heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha or from esteemed mendicants.
ai-an10:28.3.2_0: But as to how it seems to me,
ai-an10:28.3.3_0: listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-an10:28.4.1_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said,
ai-an10:28.4.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:28.4.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.4.5_0: ‘All sentient beings are sustained by food.’
ai-an10:28.4.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding this one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.4.7_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
ai-an10:28.5.1_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said,
ai-an10:28.5.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:28.5.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding two things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.5.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by two?
ai-an10:28.5.6_0: What are the teachings grouped by three?
ai-an10:28.5.7_0: There are three kinds of feelings:
ai-an10:28.5.8_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these three things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.5.9_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
ai-an10:28.6.1_0: ‘The four questions: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said,
ai-an10:28.6.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:28.6.3_0: With a mind well developed in four things—seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.6.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by four?
ai-an10:28.6.5_0: In the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
ai-an10:28.6.6_0: With a mind well developed in these four things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. ...
ai-an10:28.6.7_0: ‘One thing: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
ai-an10:28.7.1_0: ‘The five questions: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said,
ai-an10:28.7.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:28.7.3_0: With a mind well developed in five things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.7.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
ai-an10:28.7.6_0: What are the six fields of contact?
ai-an10:28.7.8_0: What are the teachings grouped by seven?
ai-an10:28.7.10_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-an10:28.7.12_0: With a mind well developed in these eight things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. ...
ai-an10:28.7.13_0: ‘Take a question, and a passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
ai-an10:28.8.1_0: ‘There are ninety things: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said,
ai-an10:28.8.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:28.8.3_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding nine things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.8.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by nine?
ai-an10:28.8.5_0: The nine abodes of sentient beings. ...
ai-an10:28.8.6_0: Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these nine things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.8.7_0: ‘Dear ninety things: question, passage for recitation, and this is what the Buddha said.
ai-an10:28.9.1_0: ‘Ten things: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said,
ai-an10:28.9.2_0: And what did I say about this?
ai-an10:28.9.3_0: Becoming well developed in ten things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.9.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:28.9.5_0: The ten ways of performing skillful deeds.
ai-an10:28.9.6_0: With a mind well developed in these ten things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life.
ai-an10:28.9.7_0: ‘Ten things: question, passage for recitation, and answer.’ That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
ai-an10:28.10.1_0: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha said in brief in ‘The Great Questions’.
ai-an10:28.10.2_0: ‘One thing: question, summary, and answer. Two ... three ... four ... five ... six ... seven ... eight ... nine ... ten things: question, summary, and answer.’”
ai-an10:28.10.3_0: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of ten questions.’
ai-an10:28.10.4_0: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.
ai-an10:28.10.5_0: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”
ai-an10:28.10.6_0: Saying “Yes, ma’am,” they got up from their seats, bowed down, circumambulated her with their right side toward her, and went to the Buddha.
ai-an10:28.10.6_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-an10:28.10.7_0: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
ai-an10:28.11.2_0: The nun Kajaṅgalikā is astute, she has great wisdom.
ai-an10:28.11.3_0: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as the nun Kajaṅgalikā.
ai-an10:28.11.4_0: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”
ai-an10:29.1.1_0: “As far as Kāsi and Kosala extend, and as far as the dominion of King Pasenadi of Kosala extends, King Pasenadi is said to be the foremost.
ai-an10:29.1.2_0: But even King Pasenadi decays and perishes.
ai-an10:29.1.3_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with anything,
ai-an10:29.2.1_0: A galaxy extends a thousand times as far as the moon and sun revolve and the shining ones light up the quarters.
ai-an10:29.2.2_0: In that galaxy there are a thousand moons, a thousand suns, a thousand Sinerus king of mountains, a thousand Indias, a thousand Western Continents, a thousand Northern Continents, a thousand Eastern Continents, four thousand oceans, four thousand Great Kings, a thousand realms of the Gods of the Four Great Kings, a thousand realms of the Gods of the Thirty-Three, of the Gods of Yama, of the Joyful Gods, of the Gods who Love to Create, of the Gods who Control the Creations of Others, and a thousand Brahmā realms.
ai-an10:29.2.3_0: As far as the galaxy extends, the Great Brahmā is said to be the foremost.
ai-an10:29.2.4_0: But even the Great Brahmā decays and perishes.
ai-an10:29.2.5_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with anything,
ai-an10:29.3.1_0: There comes a time when this world contracts.
ai-an10:29.3.2_0: As it contracts, most sentient beings migrate to the realm of streaming radiance.
ai-an10:29.3.3_0: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the sky, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.
ai-an10:29.3.4_0: When the world is contracting, the gods of streaming radiance are said to be the foremost.
ai-an10:29.3.5_0: But even the gods of streaming radiance decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.3.6_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with anything,
ai-an10:29.4.1_0: There are these ten universal dimensions of meditation.
ai-an10:29.4.3_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, non-dual and limitless.
ai-an10:29.4.4_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal water ...
ai-an10:29.4.6_0: or the meditation on universal air.
ai-an10:29.4.8_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal yellow ...
ai-an10:29.4.9_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal red ...
ai-an10:29.4.10_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal white ...
ai-an10:29.4.11_0: Someone perceives the meditation on universal space ...
ai-an10:29.4.12_0: They perceive the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, non-dual and limitless.
ai-an10:29.4.13_0: These are the ten universal dimensions of meditation.
ai-an10:29.5.1_0: The best of these ten universal dimensions of meditation is when someone perceives the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, non-dual and limitless.
ai-an10:29.5.2_0: Some sentient beings perceive it as such.
ai-an10:29.5.3_0: But even the sentient beings who have perceive decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.5.4_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with anything,
ai-an10:29.6.1_0: There are these eight dimensions of mastery.
ai-an10:29.6.3_0: Perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.
ai-an10:29.6.4_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.6.5_0: This is the first field of mastery.
ai-an10:29.7.1_0: Perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.
ai-an10:29.7.2_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.7.3_0: This is the second dimension of mastery.
ai-an10:29.8.1_0: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.
ai-an10:29.8.2_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.8.3_0: This is the third field of mastery.
ai-an10:29.9.1_0: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.
ai-an10:29.9.2_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.9.3_0: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.
ai-an10:29.10.1_0: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, blue, with blue color, blue hue, and blue tint.
ai-an10:29.10.2_0: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color, blue hue, and blue tint.
ai-an10:29.10.3_0: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, blue, with blue color, blue hue, and blue tint.
ai-an10:29.10.4_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.10.5_0: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.
ai-an10:29.11.1_0: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, yellow, with yellow color, yellow hue, and yellow tint.
ai-an10:29.11.2_0: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color, yellow hue, and yellow tint.
ai-an10:29.11.3_0: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, yellow, with yellow color, yellow hue, and yellow tint.
ai-an10:29.11.4_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.11.5_0: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.
ai-an10:29.12.1_0: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.
ai-an10:29.12.2_0: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.
ai-an10:29.12.3_0: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.
ai-an10:29.12.4_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.12.5_0: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.
ai-an10:29.13.1_0: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
ai-an10:29.13.2_0: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
ai-an10:29.13.3_0: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
ai-an10:29.13.4_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.13.5_0: This is the eighth field of mastery.
ai-an10:29.13.6_0: These are the eight dimensions of mastery.
ai-an10:29.14.1_0: The best of these dimensions of mastery is when someone, not perceiving form internally, sees visions externally, white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
ai-an10:29.14.2_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.14.3_0: Some sentient beings perceive it as such.
ai-an10:29.14.4_0: But even the sentient beings who have perceive decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.14.5_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with anything,
ai-an10:29.15.1_0: There are four ways of practice.
ai-an10:29.15.7_0: These are the four ways of practice.
ai-an10:29.16.1_0: The best of these four ways of practice is the pleasant practice with swift insight.
ai-an10:29.16.2_0: Some sentient beings practice like this.
ai-an10:29.16.3_0: But even the sentient beings who practice like this decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.16.4_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with anything,
ai-an10:29.17.6_0: One person, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, perceives the dimension of nothingness.
ai-an10:29.18.1_0: The best of these four perceptions is when a person, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, perceives the dimension of nothingness.
ai-an10:29.18.2_0: Some sentient beings perceive it as such.
ai-an10:29.18.3_0: But even the sentient beings who have perceive decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.18.4_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with anything,
ai-an10:29.19.1_0: This is the best of the convictions of outsiders, that is: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
ai-an10:29.19.2_0: When someone has such a view, you can expect
ai-an10:29.19.3_0: that they will be repulsed by continued existence,
ai-an10:29.19.4_0: and they will not be repulsed by the cessation of continued existence.
ai-an10:29.19.5_0: Some sentient beings have such a view.
ai-an10:29.19.6_0: But even the sentient beings who have views like this decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.19.7_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with anything,
ai-an10:29.20.1_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who advocate ultimate purity.
ai-an10:29.20.2_0: This is the best of the advocates of ultimate purity, that is, when someone, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-an10:29.20.3_0: They teach Dhamma in order to directly know and realize this.
ai-an10:29.20.4_0: Some sentient beings have such a doctrine.
ai-an10:29.20.5_0: But even the sentient beings who have such a doctrine decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.20.6_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with anything,
ai-an10:29.21.1_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who advocate ultimate extinguishment in this very life.
ai-an10:29.21.2_0: This is the best of those who advocate extinguishment in this very life, that is, liberation by not grasping after truly understanding the origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape of the six fields of contact.
ai-an10:29.21.3_0: Though I speak and explain like this, certain ascetics and brahmins misrepresent me with the false, hollow, lying, untruthful claim:
ai-an10:29.21.4_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama doesn’t advocate the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, sights, or feelings.’
ai-an10:29.21.5_0: But I do advocate the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, sights, and feelings. And I advocate complete extinguishment by not grasping in this very life, wishless, extinguished, and cooled.”
ai-an10:30.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an10:30.1.2_0: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala returned from combat after winning a battle and succeeding in his objective.
ai-an10:30.1.3_0: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went to the monastery.
ai-an10:30.1.4_0: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot.
ai-an10:30.1.5_0: At that time a number of monks were walking mindfully in the open air.
ai-an10:30.1.6_0: King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to them and said,
ai-an10:30.1.7_0: “Sirs, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?
ai-an10:30.1.8_0: For I want to see the Buddha.”
ai-an10:30.1.9_0: “Great king, this dwelling is closed, great king.
ai-an10:30.1.9_1: Approach it quietly, without hurrying; go onto the porch, clear your throat, and knock with the latch.
ai-an10:30.1.9_2: The Buddha will open the door.”
ai-an10:30.2.1_0: So the king approached the Buddha’s dwelling and knocked, and the Buddha opened the door.
ai-an10:30.2.2_0: Then King Pasenadi entered the Buddha’s dwelling. He bowed with his head to the Buddha’s feet, caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:
ai-an10:30.2.3_0: “Sirs, I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!
ai-an10:30.2.4_0: I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!”
ai-an10:30.3.1_0: “But great king, for what reason do you demonstrate such utmost devotion for this body, conveying your manifest love?”
ai-an10:30.3.2_0: “Sir, it’s because of my gratitude and thanks for the Buddha that I demonstrate such utmost devotion, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.4.1_0: The Buddha is practicing for the welfare and happiness of the people. He has established many people in the noble method, that is, the principles of goodness and skillfulness.
ai-an10:30.4.2_0: This is a reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.5.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha is ethical, possessing ethical conduct that is mature, noble, and skillful.
ai-an10:30.5.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.6.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha lives in the wilderness, frequenting remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
ai-an10:30.6.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.7.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-an10:30.7.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.8.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
ai-an10:30.8.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.9.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha gets to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when he wants, without trouble or difficulty. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-an10:30.9.2_0: This is another way to get to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart ...
ai-an10:30.9.2_1: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.10.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha gets the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when he wants, without trouble or difficulty.
ai-an10:30.10.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.11.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha recollects many kinds of past lives. That is:
ai-an10:30.11.1_1: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding.
ai-an10:30.11.1_2: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food.
ai-an10:30.11.1_3: There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-an10:30.11.2_0: Since he recollects many kinds of past lives,
ai-an10:30.11.2_1: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.12.1_0: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-an10:30.12.1_1: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-an10:30.12.1_2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place.
ai-an10:30.12.1_3: They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-an10:30.12.2_0: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman,
ai-an10:30.12.2_1: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.13.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-an10:30.13.2_1: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.14.1_0: Well, now, sir, I must go.
ai-an10:30.14.3_0: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”
ai-an10:30.14.4_0: Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-an10:30.14.6_0: The third sub-chapter on greatness is finished.
ai-an10:31.1.1_0: Soon afterwards Venerable Upāli approached the Buddha,
ai-an10:31.1.1_2: Then the Buddha said to Upāli,
ai-an10:31.1.2_0: “Sir, for how many reasons did the Realized One lay down training rules for his disciples and recite the monastic code?”
ai-an10:31.2.1_0: “Upāli, the Realized One laid down training rules for his disciples and recited the monastic code for ten reasons.
ai-an10:31.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:31.2.3_0: For the well-being of the Saṅgha and for the comfort of the Saṅgha. For keeping difficult persons in check and for the comfort of good-hearted mendicants. For restraining defilements that affect the present life and protecting against defilements that affect lives to come. For inspiring confidence in those without it, and increasing confidence in those who have it. For the continuation of the true teaching and the support of the training.
ai-an10:31.2.4_0: The Realized One laid down training rules for his disciples and recited the monastic code for these ten reasons.”
ai-an10:31.2.5_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-an10:32.0.3_0: 32. Suspending the Recitation of the Monastic Code
ai-an10:32.1.1_0: “Sir, how many grounds are there to suspend the recitation of the monastic code?”
ai-an10:32.1.2_0: “Upāli, there are ten grounds to suspend the recitation of the monastic code.
ai-an10:32.1.3_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:32.1.4_0: A mendicant who has committed an expulsion offense is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether someone has committed an expulsion offense is unfinished. A person who is not fully ordained is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether someone is fully ordained or not is unfinished. Someone who has resigned the training is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether someone has rejected the training or not is unfinished. A eunuch is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether someone is a eunuch is unfinished. A raper of nuns is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether or not someone is a raper of nuns is unfinished.
ai-an10:32.1.5_0: These are the ten grounds to suspend the recitation of the monastic code.”
ai-an10:33.1.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to be agreed on as a judge?”
ai-an10:33.1.2_0: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to be agreed on as a judge.
ai-an10:33.1.4_0: Take a monk who is ethical,
ai-an10:33.1.4_1: Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an10:33.1.5_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
ai-an10:33.1.6_0: He has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; he has well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
ai-an10:33.1.7_0: They’re firm and unfaltering in the training.
ai-an10:33.1.8_0: When there are opposing parties, they’re able to persuade, advocate, and convince them, make them see the other side and trust each other.
ai-an10:33.1.9_0: They’re skilled in raising and settling disciplinary issues.
ai-an10:33.1.11_0: They know how a disciplinary issue originates.
ai-an10:33.1.12_0: They know how a disciplinary issue ceases.
ai-an10:33.1.13_0: They know the practical way leading to the cessation of a disciplinary issue.
ai-an10:33.1.14_0: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to be agreed on as a judge.”
ai-an10:34.1.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to give ordination?”
ai-an10:34.1.2_0: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to give ordination.
ai-an10:34.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an10:34.1.5_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
ai-an10:34.1.6_0: He has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; he has well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
ai-an10:34.1.7_0: They’re able to nurse him or to have him attend on him.
ai-an10:34.1.8_0: He’s able to discontent, to have him sent away, or to have him sent away when he’s discontent.
ai-an10:34.1.10_0: They’re capable of wrong view, vomited up.
ai-an10:34.1.11_0: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics.
ai-an10:34.1.12_0: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher mind,
ai-an10:34.1.13_0: They’re able to encourage someone in higher wisdom.
ai-an10:34.1.14_0: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to give ordination.”
ai-an10:35.1.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to give dependence?”
ai-an10:35.1.2_0: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to give dependence.
ai-an10:35.1.4_0: Firstly, a monk is ethical, restrained in the code of conduct, with good behavior and supporters. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an10:35.1.5_0: He has learned much, and he retained them in good qualities.
ai-an10:35.1.6_0: He has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; he has well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
ai-an10:35.1.7_0: They’re able to nurse him or to have him attend on him.
ai-an10:35.1.8_0: He’s able to discontent, to have him sent away, or to have him sent away when he’s discontent.
ai-an10:35.1.10_0: They’re capable of wrong view, vomited up.
ai-an10:35.1.11_0: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics,
ai-an10:35.1.14_0: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to give dependence.”
ai-an10:36.1.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to be attended on by a novice?”
ai-an10:36.1.2_0: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to be attended on by a novice.
ai-an10:36.1.4_0: Firstly, a monk is ethical, restrained in the code of conduct, with good behavior and supporters. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an10:36.1.5_0: He has learned much, and he retained them in good qualities.
ai-an10:36.1.6_0: He has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; he has well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
ai-an10:36.1.7_0: They’re able to nurse him or to have him attend on him.
ai-an10:36.1.8_0: He’s able to discontent, to have him sent away, or to have him sent away when he’s discontent.
ai-an10:36.1.10_0: They’re capable of wrong view, vomited up.
ai-an10:36.1.11_0: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics.
ai-an10:36.1.12_0: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher mind,
ai-an10:36.1.13_0: They’re able to encourage someone in higher wisdom.
ai-an10:36.1.14_0: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to be attended on by a novice.”
ai-an10:37.1.1_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘schism in the Saṅgha’.
ai-an10:37.1.2_0: But how is there schism in the Sangha?”
ai-an10:37.1.3_0: “Upāli, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching, and what is the teaching as not the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:37.1.4_0: The ten grounds and recite the Monastic Code separately, and they do the same.
ai-an10:37.1.5_0: That is how schism in the Saṅgha is defined.”
ai-an10:38.1.2_0: But how is there unity in the Sangha?”
ai-an10:38.1.3_0: “Upāli, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as not the teaching, and what is the teaching as the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:38.1.4_0: But they don’t recite the Monastic Code or having ten grounds, nor do they recite the Monastic Code in order.
ai-an10:38.1.5_0: then there is unity in the Sangha.”
ai-an10:39.1.1_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
ai-an10:39.1.2_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘schism in the Saṅgha’.
ai-an10:39.1.3_0: But how is there schism in the Sangha?”
ai-an10:39.1.4_0: “Ānanda, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching ...
ai-an10:39.1.5_0: They proclaim what was laid down by the Buddha as not laid down by the Buddha.
ai-an10:39.1.6_0: The ten grounds and recite the Monastic Code separately, and they do the same.
ai-an10:39.1.7_0: That is how schism in the Saṅgha is defined.”
ai-an10:39.2.1_0: “But, Sir, what is the consequence of causing a schism in a united Sangha?”
ai-an10:39.2.2_0: “They bring upon themselves evil that lasts for an eon.”
ai-an10:39.2.3_0: “But sir, what is the evil that lasts for an eon?”
ai-an10:39.2.4_0: “They burn in hell for an eon, Ānanda.
ai-an10:39.3.2_0: The schismatic stays there for an eon.
ai-an10:39.3.3_0: Taking a stand against the teaching,
ai-an10:39.3.5_0: After causing schism in a harmonious Saṅgha,
ai-an10:39.3.6_0: He boils in hell for an eon.’”
ai-an10:40.1.2_0: But how is there unity in the Sangha?”
ai-an10:40.1.3_0: “Ānanda, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as not the teaching, and what is the teaching as the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:40.1.4_0: But they don’t recite the Monastic Code or having ten grounds, nor do they recite the Monastic Code in order.
ai-an10:40.1.5_0: That is how harmony in the Saṅgha is defined.”
ai-an10:40.2.1_0: “But, Sir, what is the consequence of uniting a schismatic sangha?”
ai-an10:40.2.4_0: “They rejoice in heaven for an eon, Ānanda.
ai-an10:40.3.1_0: A Saṅgha in harmony is happy,
ai-an10:40.3.2_0: as is support for those in harmony.
ai-an10:40.3.6_0: He rejoices in heaven for an eon.’”
ai-an10:40.3.8_0: The fourth sub-chapter on Upāli is finished.
ai-an10:41.1.1_0: Soon afterwards Venerable Upāli approached the Buddha,
ai-an10:41.1.1_2: Then the Buddha said to Upāli,
ai-an10:41.1.2_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason, why arguments, quarrels, and disputes arise in the Saṅgha, and the mendicants don’t live happily?”
ai-an10:41.1.3_0: “Upāli, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching, and what is the teaching as not the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:41.1.4_0: This is the cause, this is the reason why arguments, quarrels, and disputes arise in the Saṅgha, and the mendicants don’t live happily.”
ai-an10:41.1.5_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-an10:42.1.1_0: “Sir, how many roots of arguments are there?”
ai-an10:42.1.2_0: “Upāli, there are ten roots of arguments.
ai-an10:42.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching, and what is the teaching as not the teaching. They explain what is not the training as the training, and what is the training as not the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:42.1.5_0: These are the ten roots of arguments.”
ai-an10:43.1.1_0: “Sir, how many roots of arguments are there?”
ai-an10:43.1.2_0: “Upāli, there are ten roots of arguments.
ai-an10:43.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant explains what is not an offense as an offense, and what is an offense as not an offense. They explain a light offense as a serious offense, and a serious offense as a light offense. They explain an offense committed with corrupt intention as an offense not committed with corrupt intention, and an offense not committed with corrupt intention as an offense committed with corrupt intention. They explain an offense requiring rehabilitation as an offense not requiring rehabilitation, and an offense not requiring rehabilitation as an offense requiring rehabilitation. They explain an offense with redress as an offense without redress, and an offense without redress as an offense with redress.
ai-an10:43.1.5_0: These are the ten roots of arguments.”
ai-an10:44.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusinārā in a forest grove on the bank of the Sappinī river.
ai-an10:44.2.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should first check five things in themselves and establish five things in themselves.
ai-an10:44.2.2_0: What five things should they check in themselves?
ai-an10:44.2.3_0: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.2.4_0: ‘Is my bodily conduct pure and faultless?
ai-an10:44.2.5_0: Is this quality found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.2.6_0: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
ai-an10:44.2.7_0: ‘Come on, venerable, train your own bodily behavior first.’
ai-an10:44.3.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.3.2_0: ‘Is my verbal behavior pure? Do I have pure verbal behavior that is impeccable and irreproachable?
ai-an10:44.3.3_0: Is this quality found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.3.4_0: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
ai-an10:44.3.5_0: ‘Come on, venerable, train your own verbal behavior first.’
ai-an10:44.4.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.4.2_0: ‘Is my heart established in love for my spiritual companions, without resentment?
ai-an10:44.4.3_0: Is this quality found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.4.4_0: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
ai-an10:44.4.5_0: ‘Come on, venerable, establish your heart in love for your spiritual companions first.’
ai-an10:44.5.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.5.2_0: ‘Am I very learned, remembering and keeping what I’ve learned? These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. Am I very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically?
ai-an10:44.5.3_0: Is this quality found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.5.4_0: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
ai-an10:44.5.5_0: ‘Come on, venerable, memorize the scriptures first.’
ai-an10:44.6.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.6.2_0: ‘Have both monastic codes been passed down to me in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, and well judged in both the rules and accompanying material?
ai-an10:44.6.3_0: Is this quality found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.6.4_0: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
ai-an10:44.6.6_0: ‘Come on, venerable, train in the code of conduct first.’
ai-an10:44.6.7_0: These are the five things they should check in themselves.
ai-an10:44.7.1_0: What five things should they establish in themselves?
ai-an10:44.7.2_0: ‘I will speak at the right time, not at the wrong time.
ai-an10:44.7.3_0: I’ll speak the truth, not falsehood;
ai-an10:44.7.5_0: I’ll speak what’s beneficial, not what’s unbeneficial;
ai-an10:44.7.6_0: I will speak lovingly, not from secret hate.’
ai-an10:44.7.7_0: These are the five things they should establish in themselves.
ai-an10:44.7.8_0: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should first check these five things in themselves and establish these five things in themselves.”
ai-an10:45.1.1_0: “Monks, there are ten dangers in entering a royal compound.
ai-an10:45.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:45.1.3_0: Firstly, a king is sitting with his chief queen
ai-an10:45.1.5_0: When the queen sees the monk she smiles, or when the monk sees the queen he smiles.
ai-an10:45.1.7_0: ‘Surely they’ve done it, or they’re going to.’
ai-an10:45.1.8_0: This is the first drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.2.1_0: Furthermore, a king has many duties, and much to do. He has sex with one of the women but doesn’t remember.
ai-an10:45.2.4_0: ‘There is no other person else who has gone forth.
ai-an10:45.2.5_0: might be done for those who go forth?’
ai-an10:45.2.6_0: This is the second drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.3.1_0: Furthermore, a gem is lost somewhere in the royal harem.
ai-an10:45.3.3_0: ‘There is no other person else who has gone forth.
ai-an10:45.3.4_0: might be done for those who go forth?’
ai-an10:45.3.5_0: This is the third drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.4.1_0: Furthermore, secret deliberations in the royal harem are leaked outside.
ai-an10:45.4.3_0: ‘There is no other person else who has gone forth.
ai-an10:45.4.4_0: might be done for those who go forth?’
ai-an10:45.4.5_0: This is the fourth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.5.1_0: Furthermore, in a royal harem, a father longs for their son, or a son longs for his father.
ai-an10:45.5.3_0: ‘There is no other person else who has gone forth.
ai-an10:45.5.4_0: might be done for those who go forth?’
ai-an10:45.5.5_0: This is the fifth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.6.4_0: might be done for those who go forth?’
ai-an10:45.6.5_0: This is the sixth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.7.1_0: Furthermore, the king demotes someone to a lower position.
ai-an10:45.7.4_0: might be done for those who go forth?’
ai-an10:45.7.5_0: This is the seventh drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.8.1_0: Again, the king sends out the army at an inappropriate time.
ai-an10:45.8.4_0: might be done for those who go forth?’
ai-an10:45.8.5_0: This is the eighth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.9.1_0: Again, after sending out the army at an appropriate time, the king orders it to turn back while still en route.
ai-an10:45.9.4_0: might be done for those who go forth?’
ai-an10:45.9.5_0: This is the ninth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.10.1_0: Furthermore, in the royal harem there is a trampling of elephants, horses, and chariots, as well as arousing sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches that do not befit a monk.
ai-an10:45.10.2_0: This is the tenth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.10.3_0: Monks, these are the ten dangers in entering a royal compound.”
ai-an10:46.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying among the Sakyans near Kapilavatthu in Banyan Tree Monastery.
ai-an10:46.1.2_0: Then on the next sabbath several lay followers went up to the Buddha.
ai-an10:46.1.2_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-an10:46.1.3_0: “Sakyans, do you observe the sabbath with its eight factors?”
ai-an10:46.1.4_0: “Sir, sometimes we do, sometimes we don’t.”
ai-an10:46.1.5_0: “That’s your loss, Sakyans, it’s your misfortune. In this life with its fear of sorrow and death, you sometimes keep the sabbath and you sometimes don’t.
ai-an10:46.2.2_0: Take a man who earns half a dollar for an honest day’s work.
ai-an10:46.2.3_0: A person who is skilled initiative?”
ai-an10:46.3.2_0: Take a man who, for an honest day’s work, earns half a dollar.
ai-an10:46.3.3_0: A person who is skilled initiative?”
ai-an10:46.4.2_0: Take a man who, for an honest day’s work, earns two dollars ...
ai-an10:46.4.16_0: A person who is skilled initiative?”
ai-an10:46.5.2_0: Suppose that man earned a hundred or a thousand dollars every day and saved it all up. If he lived for a hundred years, would he not accumulate a large mass of wealth?”
ai-an10:46.6.2_0: Would that man, on account of that wealth, experience perfect happiness for a single day or night, or even half a day or night?”
ai-an10:46.6.5_0: “Because sensual pleasures, sir, are impermanent, hollow, false, and deceptive.”
ai-an10:46.7.1_0: “But take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for ten years, practicing in line with my instructions. They can experience perfect happiness for a hundred years, ten thousand years, or a hundred thousand years.
ai-an10:46.7.2_0: And they could become a once-returner or a non-returner, or guaranteed a stream-enterer.
ai-an10:46.8.1_0: take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for nine years ...
ai-an10:46.10.1_0: take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute.
ai-an10:46.12.9_0: Let alone two days, take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for one day, practicing in line with my instructions. They can experience perfect happiness for a hundred years, ten thousand years, or a hundred thousand years. And they could become a once-returner or a non-returner, or guaranteed a stream-enterer.
ai-an10:46.12.10_0: It’s your loss, Sakyans, it’s your misfortune. In this life with its fear of sorrow and death, you sometimes keep the sabbath and you sometimes don’t.”
ai-an10:46.12.11_0: “Well, sir, from this day forth we will observe the sabbath with its eight factors.”
ai-an10:47.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-an10:47.1.2_0: Then Mahāli the Licchavi went up to the Buddha,
ai-an10:47.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for doing bad deeds, for performing bad deeds?”
ai-an10:47.1.4_0: “Greed is a cause, Mahāli, greed is a reason for doing bad deeds, for performing bad deeds.
ai-an10:47.1.5_0: Hate is a cause of bad deeds ...
ai-an10:47.1.6_0: Delusion is a cause of bad deeds ...
ai-an10:47.1.7_0: Improper attention is a cause of bad deeds ...
ai-an10:47.1.8_0: A wrongly directed mind is a cause of bad deeds ...
ai-an10:47.1.9_0: This is the cause, Mahāli, this is the reason for doing bad deeds, for performing bad deeds.”
ai-an10:47.2.1_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for doing good deeds, for performing good deeds?”
ai-an10:47.2.2_0: “Contentment is a cause, Mahāli, contentment is a reason for doing good deeds, for performing good deeds.
ai-an10:47.2.3_0: Love is a cause of good deeds ...
ai-an10:47.2.4_0: Understanding is a cause of good deeds ...
ai-an10:47.2.5_0: Proper attention is a cause of good deeds ...
ai-an10:47.2.6_0: A rightly directed mind is a cause of good deeds ...
ai-an10:47.2.7_0: This is the cause, Mahāli, this is the reason for doing good deeds, for performing good deeds.
ai-an10:47.2.8_0: If these ten things were not found in the world, we wouldn’t see either unprincipled and immoral conduct, or principled and moral conduct.
ai-an10:47.2.9_0: But since these ten things are found in the world, we see both unprincipled and immoral conduct, and principled and moral conduct.”
ai-an10:48.0.3_0: 48. Ten Regular Reflections for a Renunciate
ai-an10:48.1.1_0: “Mendicants, one who has gone forth should often review these ten things.
ai-an10:48.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:48.2.1_0: One who has gone forth should often review this: ‘I have secured freedom from class.’
ai-an10:48.3.1_0: ‘My livelihood is tied up with others.’
ai-an10:48.5.1_0: ‘I hope there’s no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct?’
ai-an10:48.6.1_0: ‘I hope that, after examination, sensible spiritual companions don’t reproach any aspect of my ethics?’
ai-an10:48.7.1_0: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved.’
ai-an10:48.8.1_0: ‘I am the owner of my deeds and heir to my deeds. Deeds are my womb, my relative, and my refuge.
ai-an10:48.9.1_0: I shall be the heir of whatever deeds I do, whether good or bad.’
ai-an10:48.10.1_0: ‘As the days and nights flit by, what sort of person am I becoming?’
ai-an10:48.11.1_0: ‘Do I love to stay in empty huts?’
ai-an10:48.12.1_0: ‘Do I have any superhuman distinctions in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, so that when my spiritual companions question me on my deathbed I will not be embarrassed?’
ai-an10:48.13.1_0: One who has gone forth should often review these ten things.”
ai-an10:49.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these ten things exist because of the body.
ai-an10:49.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:49.1.3_0: Cold, heat, hunger, thirst, feces, urine, restraint of body, speech, and livelihood, and the will to live that leads to future lives.
ai-an10:49.1.4_0: These are the ten things that exist because of the body.”
ai-an10:50.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an10:50.1.2_0: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from alms-round, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall. They were arguing, quarreling, and disputing, wounding each other with barbed words.
ai-an10:50.2.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall.
ai-an10:50.2.1_1: where he sat down on a prepared seat.
ai-an10:50.2.2_0: and told the mendicants what had happened.
ai-an10:50.2.3_0: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”
ai-an10:50.3.1_0: “Sir, after the meal, on return from alms-round, we sat together in the assembly hall, arguing, quarreling, and disputing, wounding each other with barbed words.”
ai-an10:50.3.2_0: “Mendicants, this is not appropriate for you gentlemen who have gone forth in faith from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-an10:50.4.1_0: There are ten warm-hearted qualities that make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.4.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:50.4.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an10:50.4.5_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.5.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.6.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates. ...
ai-an10:50.6.2_0: When a mendicant has good friends,
ai-an10:50.6.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.7.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully. ...
ai-an10:50.7.2_0: When a mendicant is easy to admonish,
ai-an10:50.7.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.8.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work. ...
ai-an10:50.8.2_0: When a mendicant is skilled and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties, this is an understanding of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.
ai-an10:50.8.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.9.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training. ...
ai-an10:50.9.2_0: When a mendicant loves the teachings,
ai-an10:50.9.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.10.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities. ...
ai-an10:50.10.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.11.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. ...
ai-an10:50.11.2_0: When a mendicant is content with any kind of robes,
ai-an10:50.11.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, helping the Saṅgha to live in harmony and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.12.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
ai-an10:50.12.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, helping the Saṅgha to live in harmony and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.13.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-an10:50.13.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, helping the Saṅgha to live in harmony and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.14.1_0: These ten warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.”
ai-an10:50.14.3_0: The fifth sub-chapter on abuse is finished.
ai-an10:50.15.1_0: Yet two disputes that have been settled,
ai-an10:50.15.5_0: The first sub-chapter on dismissing is finished.
ai-an10:51.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an10:51.2.1_0: “Mendicants, if a mendicant isn’t skilled in the ways of another’s mind, then they should train themselves: ‘I will be skilled in the ways of my own mind.’
ai-an10:51.3.1_0: And how is a mendicant skilled in the ways of thought?
ai-an10:51.3.2_0: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.
ai-an10:51.3.3_0: But if they don’t see any dirt or blemish there, they’re happy with that, thinking:
ai-an10:51.3.5_0: In the same way, checking is very helpful for a mendicant’s skillful qualities.
ai-an10:51.3.6_0: ‘Am I often covetous or not? Am I often malicious or not? Am I often overcome with dullness and drowsiness or not? Am I often restless or not? Am I often doubtful or not? Am I often irritable or not? Am I often corrupted in mind or not? Am I often disturbed in body or not? Am I often energetic or not? Am I often immersed in samādhi or not?’
ai-an10:51.4.1_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
ai-an10:51.4.2_0: ‘I am often covetous, malicious, overcome with dullness and drowsiness, restless, doubtful, angry, defiled in mind, disturbed in body, lazy, and not immersed in samādhi.’ In order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.’
ai-an10:51.4.3_0: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire.
ai-an10:51.4.3_1: If they’re extinguished in this way, they’ll apply outstanding enthusiasm or effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
ai-an10:51.4.4_0: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm ...
ai-an10:51.5.1_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
ai-an10:51.5.2_0: ‘I am often content, kind-hearted, rid of dullness and drowsiness, calm, confident, loving, pure in mind, undisturbed in body, energetic, and immersed in samādhi.’ Grounded on those skillful qualities, they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.”
ai-an10:51.5.3_0: First the first part of the body.

ai-an10:52.3.1_0: And how is a mendicant skilled in the ways of thought?

ai-an10:52.5.2_1: they often review, ‘I have immersion.’ In order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

ai-an10:52.5.4_0: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm ...
ai-an10:52.6.1_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
ai-an10:52.6.2_1: they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.”
ai-an10:53.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I don’t praise stagnation in skillful qualities, let alone decline.
ai-an10:53.1.2_0: I praise growth in skillful qualities, not stagnation or decline.
ai-an10:53.2.1_0: And how is there decline in skillful qualities, not stagnation or growth?
ai-an10:53.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has a certain degree of faith, ethics, generosity, wisdom, and eloquence. Those qualities neither decline nor grow in them.
ai-an10:53.2.3_0: I call this decline in skillful qualities, not stagnation or growth.
ai-an10:53.2.4_0: This is how there’s decline in skillful qualities, not stagnation or growth.
ai-an10:53.3.1_0: And how is there stagnation in skillful qualities, not decline or growth?
ai-an10:53.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has a certain degree of faith, ethics, generosity, wisdom, and eloquence. Those qualities neither decline nor grow in them.
ai-an10:53.3.3_0: I call this stagnation in skillful qualities, not decline or growth.
ai-an10:53.3.4_0: This is how there’s stagnation in skillful qualities, not decline or growth.
ai-an10:53.4.1_0: And how is there growth in skillful qualities, not stagnation or decline?
ai-an10:53.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has a certain degree of faith, ethics, generosity, wisdom, and eloquence. Those qualities neither stagnate nor decline in them.
ai-an10:53.4.3_0: I call this growth in skillful qualities, not stagnation or decline.
ai-an10:53.4.4_0: This is how there’s growth in skillful qualities, not stagnation or decline.
